messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 61 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Solving Problems on Generalized Convex Graphs via Mim-WidthBrettell and Paulusma received support from the Leverhulme Trust (RPG-2016-258). Bonomo received support from CONICET (PIP 11220200100084CO) and UBACyT (20020170100495BA and 20020160100095BA). Brettell was also supported by a Rutherford Foundation Postdoctoral Fellowship, administered by the Royal Society Te Apārangi. An extended abstract of the paper appeared in the proceedings of WADS 2021 [7].

Paper Abstract: Abstract A bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)𝐺𝐴𝐵𝐸G=(A,B,E) is ℋℋ{\cal H}-convex, for some family of graphs ℋℋ{\cal H}, if there exists a graph H∈ℋ𝐻ℋH\in{\cal H} with V​(H)=A𝑉𝐻𝐴V(H)=A such that the set of neighbours in A𝐴A of each b∈B𝑏𝐵b\in B induces a connected subgraph of H𝐻H. Many 𝖭𝖯𝖭𝖯\mathsf{NP}-complete problems, including problems such as Dominating Set, Feedback Vertex Set, Induced Matching and List k𝑘k-Colouring, become polynomial-time solvable for ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}-convex graphs when ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} is the set of paths. In this case, the class of ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}-convex graphs is known as the class of convex graphs. The underlying reason is that the class of convex graphs has bounded mim-width. We extend the latter result to families of ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}-convex graphs where (i) ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} is the set of cycles, or (ii) ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} is the set of trees with bounded maximum degree and a bounded number of vertices of degree at least 333. As a consequence, we can strengthen a large number of results on generalized convex graphs known in the literature via one general and relatively short proof. To complement result (ii), we show that the mim-width of ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}-convex graphs is unbounded if ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} is the set of trees with arbitrarily large maximum degree or an arbitrarily large number of vertices of degree at least 333. In this way we are able to determine complexity dichotomies for the aforementioned graph problems. We prove our results via a more refined width-parameter analysis. This yields an even clearer picture of which width parameters are bounded for classes of ℋℋ{\cal H}-convex graphs.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 61 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 61"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Graph functionality",
        "Graph classes with structured neighborhoods and algorithmic applications",
        "More applications of the d-neighbor equivalence: Connectivity and acyclicity constraints",
        "Node multiway cut and subset feedback vertex set on graphs of bounded mim-width",
        "Twin-width I: tractable FO model checking",
        "On the thinness and proper thinness of a graph",
        "Solving problems on generalized convex graphs via mim-width",
        "Thinness of product graphs",
        "Fair division of a graph",
        "Graph Classes: A Survey",
        "On the linear structure and clique-width of bipartite permutation graphs",
        "Understanding model counting for beta-acyclic CNF-formulas",
        "Bounding the mim-width of hereditary graph classes",
        "List k𝑘k-colouring Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡{P}_{t}-free graphs: a mim-width perspective",
        "On planar supports for hypergraphs",
        "Boolean-width of graphs",
        "Fast dynamic programming for locally checkable vertex subset and vertex partitioning problems",
        "Complexity of domination, hamiltonicity and treewidth for tree convex bipartite graphs",
        "Polynomial-time data reduction for the Subset Interconnection Design problem",
        "Hard coloring problems in low degree planar bipartite graphs",
        "List 333-coloring Ptsubscript𝑃𝑡{P}_{t}-free graphs with no induced 111-subdivision of K1,ssubscript𝐾1𝑠{K}_{1,s}",
        "Upper bounds to the clique width of graphs",
        "List coloring in the absence of a linear forest",
        "Clique-width for hereditary graph classes",
        "On list k𝑘k-coloring convex bipartite graphs",
        "The complexity of colouring problems on dense graphs",
        "Maximum matching in a convex bipartite graph",
        "On the clique-width of some perfect graph classes",
        "On the complexity of combinatorial auctions: Structured item graphs and hypertree decomposition",
        "Width parameters beyond tree-width and their applications",
        "Deciding k𝑘k-colorability of P5subscript𝑃5{P}_{5}-free graphs in polynomial time",
        "Linear mim-width of trees",
        "Narrowing the complexity gap for colouring (Cs,Pt)subscript𝐶𝑠subscript𝑃𝑡({C}_{s},{P}_{t})-free graphs",
        "Precoloring extension 3: Classes of perfect graphs",
        "Bounded Width Graph Classes in Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Mim-width II. The Feedback Vertex Set problem",
        "Classes of intersection digraphs with good algorithmic properties",
        "Feedback vertex sets on restricted bipartite graphs",
        "Tractable feedback vertex sets in restricted bipartite graphs",
        "Recent developments on graphs of bounded clique-width",
        "A width parameter useful for chordal and co-comparability graphs",
        "Personal communication",
        "Circular convex bipartite graphs: Maximum matching and hamiltonian circuits",
        "Efficient algorithms for finding maximum matchings in convex bipartite graphs and related problems",
        "Restricted bipartite graphs: Comparison and hardness results",
        "Circular convex bipartite graphs: Feedback vertex sets",
        "Tractable connected domination for restricted bipartite graphs",
        "Independent domination: Reductions from circular- and triad-convex bipartite graphs to convex bipartite graphs",
        "The stable set problem and the thinness of a graph",
        "Approximating clique-width and branch-width",
        "Dominating induced matching in some subclasses of bipartite graphs",
        "Maximum weight induced matching in some subclasses of bipartite graphs",
        "Domination in some subclasses of bipartite graphs",
        "Clique-width of graphs defined by one-vertex extensions",
        "Graph minors. X. Obstructions to tree-decomposition",
        "Hardness of computing width parameters based on branch decompositions over the vertex set",
        "Independent domination on tree convex bipartite graphs",
        "Algorithms for vertex partitioning problems on partial k-trees",
        "New Width Parameters of Graphs",
        "Tree convex bipartite graphs: NP-complete domination, hamiltonicity and treewidth",
        "Feedback vertex sets on tree convex bipartite graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 61 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Solving Problems on Generalized Convex Graphs via Mim-WidthBrettell and Paulusma received support from the Leverhulme Trust (RPG-2016-258). Bonomo received support from CONICET (PIP 11220200100084CO) and UBACyT (20020170100495BA and 20020160100095BA). Brettell was also supported by a Rutherford Foundation Postdoctoral Fellowship, administered by the Royal Society Te Apārangi. An extended abstract of the paper appeared in the proceedings of WADS 2021 [7]., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
